content: After a month and a half of intense work, I can proudly say that Chebyshev's inequality is ready for review!

"monovary" has very few hits on google -- there's someone on Tumblr, there's the disease mono, and then there's the mathlib docs. Is it worth explaining what the word means?? I don't think it's a standard maths term, at least in UK English.
In fact I came up with it.
monovary f g means ∀ i j, f i < f j → g j ≤ g i. How would you state that in words?
I definitely wouldn't make a word up
This is tough really, I mean in some sense I might make a word up, but then I'd have to explain what it meant in lots of places. "Weakly antitone" or something? I don't know :-/
Also, you could also weaken the < to ≤, right?
Not so clear if f isn't injective, right?
The idea is that it means that f and g vary together. Note that this is a symmetric relation.

If f : ι → α, g : ι → β, it means that one can order ι such that both f and g are monotone. The point is that

  • actually one cannot order ι like so in full generality
  • this condition doesn't need an order on ι at all to be stated and proved

Yaël Dillies said:

The idea is that it means that f and g vary together. Note that this is a symmetric relation.

“Covariant” fits this description. I understand that name is taken for other purposes, but with Damiano's suggestion this could be turned into covariant_with
covariant is usually used as a unary relation though. How about covariate?
I've added explanations in the lemma docstrings.
docs#monovary is already in mathlib, so if you really want me to rename it I will do it in a subsequent PR.
I mostly really want Chebyshev's inequality to hit master because Szemerédi's regularity lemma depends on it.
